title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SACRAMENTO – On a night where the final score failed to capture the historic nature of the contest, Mitch Richmond authored a masterpiece. The Sacramento Kings’ guard delivered a performance for the ages, pouring in a career-high 47 points to single-handedly will his team to a 97-92 victory over the Detroit Pistons in 1997.

From the opening tip, Richmond was an unstoppable force. He carved through the Pistons’ defense with a ruthless efficiency, a one-man offensive clinic that left defenders grasping at air. His 47 points weren't just a high volume; they were a testament to his all-around scoring prowess, coming from every spot on the floor. While teammate Olden Polynice provided a crucial double-double with 15 points and 18 rebounds, the night belonged unequivocally to Richmond.

The Pistons, led by Grant Hill’s characteristically solid 27 points, fought valiantly to keep pace. Hill’s all-around effort and Terry Mills' 19 points kept Detroit within striking distance throughout the tense battle. But every time the visitors threatened to seize momentum, Richmond answered with a cold-blooded jumper or a driving layup, silencing the runs and steadying his team.

In the game's final, desperate minutes, it was Richmond who iced the victory from the free-throw line, capping his legendary night. The final horn sounded on a 97-92 Kings win, but the true story was the singular, dominant display from number 23. Richmond’s 47-point eruption wasn’t just a win; it was a historic statement etched into the annals of the franchise.
